definitions.definition: to cover something completely in paper or other material, for example when you are giving it as a present
definitions.sensetop: wrap something upwrap somethingwrap something in somethingwrap something up in something

examples.text: He spent the evening wrapping up the Christmas presents.
individually wrapped chocolates
Each apple was wrapped in paper.
The cheese is cut and wrapped in plastic.
fish and chips wrapped up in newspaper

definitions.definition: to cover something/somebody in material, for example in order to protect it/them
definitions.sensetop: wrap A in Bwrap A up in Bwrap yourself in somethingwrap yourself up in somethingwrap B round/around A

examples.text: Wrap the meat in foil before you cook it.
I wrapped the baby up in a blanket.
He tossed her a towel. ‘Wrap yourself in that.’
She wrapped herself up in a long shawl.
I wrapped a blanket around the baby.
Christine was wrapped up in one of the blankets.
She wrapped the child carefully in a blanket.
A scarf was wrapped around his neck.
The nurse wrapped a bandage tightly around my ankle.
His **arms were wrapped around** her waist.
He **wrapped his arms** tightly **around** her waist.
He wrapped his hands around my neck and tried to strangle me.
She's got a towel wrapped around her head.

definitions.definition: to cause a word or text to be carried over to a new line as the end of the previous line is reached by the writer; to be carried over in this way

examples.text: How can I wrap the text around?
The text wraps around if it is too long to fit the screen.

definitions.definition: to be so involved with somebody/something that you do not pay enough attention to other people or things

examples.text: They are completely wrapped up in their children.
She was so wrapped up in her work that she didn’t realize how late it was.

definitions.definition: to persuade somebody to do anything that you want

examples.text: She has always been able to wrap her parents around her little finger.
